content.text:
A valve in the cylinder shown in <image 1> has a cross-sectional area of 11 cm2 with a pressure of 735 kPa inside the cylinder and 99 kPa outside.How large a force is needed to open the valve?

A. F=689.4N
B. F=660.5N
C. F=699.6N
D. F=709.6N

To find the force needed to open the valve, we need to calculate the difference in pressure acting on the valve. The pressure difference is given by:

\[ \Delta P = P_{\text{inside}} - P_{\text{outside}} \]

Given:
- \( P_{\text{inside}} = 735 \, \text{kPa} \)
- \( P_{\text{outside}} = 99 \, \text{kPa} \)

So,
\[ \Delta P = 735 \, \text{kPa} - 99 \, \text{kPa} = 636 \, \text{kPa} \]

To convert kPa to N/m² (Pa, we use the conversion factor:
\[ 1 \, \text{kPa} = 10^3 \, \text{Pa} \]

Thus,
\[ \Delta P = 636 \, \text{kPa} \times 10^3 \, \text{Pa/kPa} = 636 \times 10^3 \, \text{Pa} \]

Now, we calculate the force using the area of the valve:
\[ F = \Delta P \times A_{\text{valve}} \]

Given:
- \( A_{\text{valve}} = 11 \, \text{cm}^2 = 11 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{m}^2 \)

So,
\[ F = 636 \times 10^3 \, \text{Pa} \times 11 \times 10^{-4} \, \text{m}^2 \]

\[ F = 636 \times 11 \, \text{N/m}^2 \]

\[ F = 6996 \, \text{N} \]

Therefore, the force needed to open the valve is approximately 6996 N, which corresponds to option C.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
